I won't claim to know everything about cars, I would struggle to fix a car if someone gave me a step by step 'Fixing a car for dummies' book. That said, this is a good start for anyone remotely interested in fixing/repairing/replacing parts.   While there are some things I could criticize, like the 'instructions not clear enough - private parts stuck in engine block' tutorial, it's quite easy to get into and play with little hand-holding. The part repair system could use a little work imho, the paint shop seems a bit redundant at times, the auction camera needs a bit of fixing, and some other small things.  Overall for a game of this style, having that balance between a gearhead's game and a general indie style game is hard to get right. This game gets it right. It has enough depth and detail to actually make me stop and think about what I'm doing and what steps I should take to complete the repair, but not too much that I have to call my mechanic friends/family and ask them what I need to do.  The game is easy to get into and very fun to play, again balancing gameplay and detail/realism. The number of times I've had to replace a crankshaft after I've already taken apart the clutch housing and reassembled it......  There are a few things that needed work, but mostly just quality of life improvements that could be changed/added in a patch. No major problems to speak of.  I wish some of the 2014 features were there, like the sense of progression from a garage to a multi-car shop, or the 'replace the missing parts from my new used car purchase'.  Yes you will replace brakes a thousand times, yes you will change thousands of filters, yes you will find the same problems coming up time after time. This is the life of a mechanic. Cars need brakes, cars need new filters, mechanical things break, and often times it's the same things that break. I would recommend that you see the 'monotony' as a more realistic representation of how it is to fix cars in a shop. Your car will need new oil, it will need a new timing belt at least once in its life, it's just a fact to live with.  The thing I personally like, having recently gotten to that point, is once you can purchase a parking garage and go to the auto auction to purchase broken down piles of scrap, and turn them into like-new beauties to sell. The trailer/intro video shows this, starting with a car that may be missing half of the body, trying to repair as many parts as possible to save money, and buying what you can't fix. By the end you can decide whether to just replace the really bad parts, or completely renovate the body, engine, and suspension to brand new quality. It adds a sense of accomplishment to the end game (which some may say is desperately needed after changing 1000 brake pads), and keeps you playing.   TL;DR: It can be boring, but it's worth it to anyone even remotely interested in cars. Just buy it. (Though if still in doubt - wait for a sale, $20 USD may be a bit steep for some)

This game is fun and a good tool for locating and replacing parts of a car. I have some experience in auto repair and other misc. hardware as I'm a maintenance mechanic for the USPS. Since I'm no expert in repairing cars and I like to learn, I enjoy this game and I've learned quite a bit from the repair jobs I've done so far.  At the time of this review I'm only a few hours into it but already I notice some things I would like to see added for extra realism. For example, hoses (air, radiator and others) battery cables and other major wires, various fluids like washer, brake, transmission etc. and gaskets in the engine would be a nice touch.   Something else that would help with the immersion would be to have different size wrenches and sockets with ratchets to use on different size bolts and nuts.   I think it's important to have a lot of different parts for the different cars as most cars take different parts in real life; at least for the larger more important parts. That would be nice to have to look up the make/model in the computer to get the right part. :) Honestly I don't think it wouldn't be that hard to add that if only they added part numbers to the car part inventory. Finally I would like to see options of stock, upgraded and high performance parts so you can upgrade the cars you buy. Overall though the game has potential to take many hours of fun and learning. Recommended.

There are quite a lot of pros and only a few cons to the game. Mind you, I will be comparing the older version to the newer version.  Pros: -It is not very laggy: The biggest issue I had with the older version was that I set my game to the lowest video settings, but I still kept on lagging. This game takes that and throws it in the bin. With the same computer and same specs, the 2015 version was much more smoother than the 2014 version. I had at least 30fps all the way, whereas I would have 15-20fps on the 2014 version.  -Interesting Campaign Mode: The one in CMS2014 was very controlled, you were given the same puzzle as everyone else who played the game. This gives you the choice to select the orders you want to take, and that is a game changer. No longer do you HAVE to do an order. You get to pick what you want to do. i.e I don't feel like fixing that guy's brakes, so I'll just select the order with the engine problems instead. This helps to make the game much more smoother and much more playable. -Much fewer glitches: I had a problem with CMS2014, and that was my order #43 glitched and I couldn't finish the order no matter how closely I followed the instructions. Since this is a newer game, we don't have as many glitches anymore. This game is being constantly updated, so it allows for improvement all the time.  -Cool DLCs: We have had two DLCs come out by the time I am writing this review, Visual Tuning and Young Timer. Young Timer is free, with the nice little Fiat 500 lookalike. The Visual Tuning DLC does cost some money, however it is much more cheaper compared to the price tags on the other DLCs.   Cons: -Time Consuming: Unless you are an absolute car bore who likes fixing the cars in this game like I do, you are not going to have a fun time. This is a simulator of what mechanics do on a daily basis, so ofcourse it is going to be time consuming, what did you expect?  -Unlockables: In CMS2014, we had the OBD scanner as a tool since the beginning of the game. Why do we need to work on 10 cars maximum in order to unlock the tool that we had for a long time in the previous game? They could've let some tools remain like they were in the previous game. However, it does add for an interesting aspect to the gameplay, because now you get to work for the things you really want. Although that is interesting to me, it might not be to the other gamers.  -Repair Uncertainty: Now again, unless you are a car enthusiast that finds these innovations interesting to the gameplay, you are probably not going to like the fact that there is a chance that the item you repair may not be fixed successfully.   Overall, I think they did an excellent job with the new 2015 simulator. The new additional features are absolutely worth every single penny of that price tag. This new game completely demolishes the other older one, and I am not saying this because my CMS2014 Order #43 did not work. I genuinely believe this new game is a huge step forward from the previous one. I can now only imagine how much greater the 2016 version will be, definitely a rival to the upcoming Street Tuning Revolution. I am only joking, that game is a total in depth tuning game and it will take Red Dot Games a little while to catch up to that level, eventhough in my opinion it is very close. Then again, I have not played Street Tuning Evolution yet, so I can't tell the gap there might exist between the two games. CMS2016, that is a game definitely to look forward to.

Car Mechanic simulator is a TON of fun. I've lost more than a few hours playing this game (a lot of offline hours not counted at time of review here). I'd strongly recommend this to anyone who has an interest in learning about cars, but doesn't have an extra car they can risk working on. Here's a quick list of pros and cons of the game:  Pros: - Great concept and parts. You get work with a lot of really deep and interesting parts on a surprising number of different car models. - Great progression. For the most part, the game starts you off with an easy fix (outer tie rods, brake pads, calipers, etc), and then builds up the difficulty by making you diagnose the problem, and giving you the tools and education to make that diagnosis. - Impressive graphics. Nothing stunning, but for a game of this caliber, it's got great visuals for hundreds of different car parts. - GREAT with Steam Controller. Load up a good Config, and have a blast. -Educational. Seriously, this game taught me a lot more about cars than I would've imagined. It won't turn you into a master mechanic, but it may help give you an idea of what's going wrong with a car, and maybe even give you the motivation to look up some How-To videos on youtube.  Cons: - Restrictive. The game deals almost exclusively with the engine, suspension, and exhaust, and the only fluid you'll encounter is an oil change. While that's not too bad, I would've loved to see some involvement with a vehicle's AC system. Additionally, it doesn't take into account steering, brake, or transmission fluids, or well-placed oil which is a little disappointing. - Unrealistic. In this game, you can pop off an Outer Tie Rod with a single screw- don't try doing that in real life, or you'll find yourself calling for a tow truck. While I understand the appeal to fun, a lot of parts just have this overwhelming sense of easiness about removing/replacing them. - Occasionally frustrating. The green/yellow/red outlines for parts can be a help, or a big hinderance when trying to figure out what part needs to be removed before the piece you've selected. While it's not a bad system by any means, it's in desperate need of some alternative options. Also, I don't know what car the Maluch was modeled after, but I hope the factory that made it burns down. - Lack of customization. All of your upgrades concern either improving your maintenance speed (why?) or adding OBD/Compression/Electronic testers. You can unlock a paint shop, test path and parking lot, but your garage is never given any real options to make it feel like home. - Lack of endgame. In a perfect world, you'd combine this game and, a decent racing game. While fixing a car, or filling your lot with top-of-the-line beauties is nice, it's hard to get excited when there's not much room to have any fun with them. All this horsepower, and no room to gallop!  All in all, CMS2015 is a lot of fun. If you're on the fence, wait until one of it's awesome sales roll around. It's definitely worth $20, and the DLC (aside from the Maluch) are all worth checking out.

So much, yet so little..,  First of all, I thoroughly enjoy this game, I really do. I find myself perpetually visiting the site in order to see what new features and DLCs are available to satisfy this newly created obsession of putting wonderful machines together in different ways that I could never hope to afford on a garbage man's salary.   When I first purchased Car Mechanic Simulator 2015, it was one of those titles on my wishlist that I'd hoped would finally give me enough of that car-mod junkie fix I was looking for. My feelings might be mixed on that one though. I played a game called Street Legal Racing (Redline) for a while that allowed you to put some cars together, but was extremely limited without the plethora of User Mods available out there (unfortunately, they cause the game to crash as often as -insert expletive here). What it did do right however, was the customizeability, and a nod to the racing genre if you felt like pursuing the in-game 'game'.  Ok, let's start with what CMS 2015 is not. It is not a 'Need For Speed' clone, and that is Ok. As titillating as the prospect of racing a hard worked, hard earned car is around a fictional NÃ¼rburgring facsimile with 15 sirens blaring in the background, I am of the mind that even with a AAA budget, you can either do one thing or the other very well but not both. CMS 2015 focuses on the simulatory aspects of building up your virtual baby with a level of detail that pleases and surprises.   You start out with a workshop and some car repair jobs to choose from. As you progress, you gain some cash and leveling points that you can spend on equipment and such. Without delving into too many details so as to stay on point, you get to purchase or fix different components ranging from the suspension to the engine and really get into the 'nuts and bolts' of things. After 20 or so hours and a real sense of accomplishment, I felt myself wishing that I could get even further detail into the parts I was dealing with.   I was satisfied with changing things like cylinder heads and screwing on the bolts, but I kind of felt like 'where is the head gasket?' That pesky thing that once caused me an overdraft and a scolding from my manager for coming in late. Another thing I desperately wanted, was to take Mr. Bean's car and drop some American V8 muscle in it with 21 inch rims and a boeing wing for downforce. Unfortunately and inexplicably, you can't! It seems to me that the foundations of the game are solid enough to support this though and I do really hope to see something like this very soon.   In conclusion, the aspects that are included are very well polished. The assortment of cars work as unique puzzles that need specific pieces to fit in the right order and give you a greater appreciation than the sum of their parts. Yet, more detailed problems can be fleshed out to create greater challenges, as well as interesting combinations that could increase the longevity of the game (not to mention better custom modding) by leaps and bounds.  Either way, I want more!

I'm on the fence about this one. I think Car Mechanic Simulator is a tremendous first step, however it ultimately fell short of what I was hoping for.  The game boils down to an interactive set of 3d car models. These models allow you to disassemble and reassemble engines, drive trains, and so on. This is definitely neat, but in itself only has so much enjoyment before things get repetitive.   The illusion of running a repair shop almost works but the finer points of running a business are completely lost. There are always more customers waiting, no matter how long you take, or how poorly you did. Diagnosing problems seems almost trivial, just look for rusty components as you wrench things apart. I want to like this, but I ran out of challenges a while ago. All that remains is the grind of XP and money.  This game needs more of something. I would personally love to see engine tuning and performance simulated to some degree. Other options would be expanding the business model of running a repair shop, or perhaps adding more realism to the repairs themselves. A broken part isn't just a rust texture after all.
